body.text1:
Si­murgh, al­so known as the king of birds, is de­scribed as a com­pos­ite crea­ture ‚Äî with a pea­cock tail, falcon body, a dog's head, li­on claws, and even fish scales. These fea­tures sig­ni­fied her dom­i­nance over land, air, and wa­ter. Bundahishn 13.10 classified Saƒìna as a bird and described her with three fingershttp://www.avesta.org/mp/grb12.htm#chap13She is thought to be gi­gan­tic, with the ca­pac­i­ty to car­ry an ele­phant or a whale. The sweep of her wings could dis­perse the clouds and cast a shad­ow so im­mense that it ri­valed the size of moun­tains.
In some ver­sions, Si­murgh is de­scribed with a hu­man head and fe­male breasts, and even in the other ver­sions, it is de­pic­ted as a fe­male bird. According to an ancient Mittani tale, Simurgh lived for 1700 years before bursting into flames and is rebornhttps://www.worldanvil.com/w/alam-cranial/a/simurgh-article ‚Äî much like the Greek Phoenix. After Islamization, Simurgh loses its sacred status but continues to exist in arts, folklore, and lit­er­a­ture.
In Rudaki's rendition of Pa√±chatantra, known as Kalila wa-Dimna in Perso-Arabic, there is a fable about Simurgh. In this tale, Simurgh is portrayed as a kind and honest king of birds. For example, it narrates how Simurgh rescues the chicks of a bird named Taitoo from a river monster:
PodshƒÅh Simurgh, daryoro biburd,
Khonayo bacha bad-on Taitoo supurd...c

King Simurgh, on the sea's vast spree,
Returned the home and kids to Taitoo with glee.
